mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Freal%20estate%2Four%20insights%2Fthe%20new%20real%20estate%20investment%20edge%20tech%20enabled%20brand%20cx%20and%20loyalty%2Fthe-new-real-estate-investment-edge-tech-enabled-brand-cx-and-loyalty.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="the-new-real-estate-investment-edge-tech-enabled-brand-cx-and-loyalty" data-layer-report-name="the-new-real-estate-investment-edge-tech-enabled-brand-cx-and-loyalty>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (9 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Customer experience (CX) and loyalty</strong> are ubiquitous concepts in consumer-facing industries. But in the real estate world, only the hospitality sector is known for a laser focus on consumer experiences that inspire customer loyalty and build brands. It doesn’t have to be this way. Large single-family residential (SFR) and multifamily residential (MFR) platforms now have the scale to build brands that clearly communicate a quality promise and make tenants want to stay.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by Alex Wolkomir, Michael Hales, and <a href="/our-people/vaibhav-gujral">Vaibhav Gujral</a>, with Laura Campbell, Nicolette Lewis, and Sam O’Gorman, representing views from McKinsey’s Real Estate Practice.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>With an array of premium finishes and residential amenities now commonplace, real estate operators are increasingly aware that economic returns often hinge on creating memorable moments for tenants. What might not be as obvious is the sea change in CX, which has long been understood to involve putting more money and personnel behind a property. The radical difference in 2024 is that operators can upgrade the tenant experience while also saving money—and in a way that can yield better returns for properties. At a time when the high cost of real estate is a major tenant concern, a way to improve the offering without increasing costs can be a welcome innovation for numerous stakeholders.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Memorable brand experiences, combined with the right data and technology to personalize touchpoints—including generative AI (gen AI) and digital marketing platforms—can stimulate willingness to choose a given property, higher renewal rates, and lifetime loyalty. Our experience working with numerous residential players has demonstrated that there is a premium of up to 15 percent between the highest- and lowest-performing players in a market, controlled for similar building characteristics (such as location, age, and amenities).</p>
<p>The highest-performing companies have numerous things in common, including technology investments that enable personalization (such as emails that remember a tenant’s birthday or pet’s name), new operating and staffing models (such as centralized leasing and renewals teams that serve multiple buildings), investments in brand advertising, and digital touchpoints that create transparency (such as an app for tenants to check on the status of maintenance requests). Tenants clearly perceive more value in buildings managed this way, and this value flows directly to top-line revenue and net operating income (NOI).</p>
<p>To be sure, technology is never the stand-alone superstar. Instead, <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/rewired-to-outcompete">when companies rewire to create new ways of working</a>, tech can enable fresh ways to operate and serve residents. The key for residential real estate owners and operators is to <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/how-generative-ai-can-boost-consumer-marketing">define the CX moments that matter</a> along a resident’s journey, underpinned by a branded North Star.</p>
<p>This article describes how real estate companies can approach CX to encourage loyalty and build brands imbued with meaning by using an eight-step framework. For the purposes of this article, loyalty refers to tenants who perceive value in a real estate brand and respond by either renewing leases or looking for their next home within the same family of brands.</p>
<h2>How residential real estate can react to a shifting experiential landscape</h2>
<p>Across industries, changing consumer interaction preferences and a proliferation of new technologies, including AI, are enabling companies to interact with customers in new and creative ways. In the post-COVID-19 landscape, proactive self-service that concretely answers specific questions is often customers’ first choice, preferred over interacting with a sales representative.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="147a4f42-01ca-4e90-8578-603f9b87cd6d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="147a4f42-01ca-4e90-8578-603f9b87cd6d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Stephanie Clifford, “Retailers add gadgets for shoppers at ease with technology,” <em>New York Times</em>, March 9, 2012.</span></span></span></a></span> <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/next-in-loyalty-eight-levers-to-turn-customers-into-fans">Loyalty is an evolving concept</a>, partly because consumers often drop out of loyalty programs after reaping the sign-up reward.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="17ef1aee-bf32-4148-859e-60a43f95a63b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="17ef1aee-bf32-4148-859e-60a43f95a63b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nathaniel Meyersohn, “Best Buy, Dunkin’ and Starbucks changed their rewards programs. Then came the backlash,” CNN, January 14, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Instead, an omnichannel strategy, whereby consumers interact with brands across platforms and continually receive personalized recognition for their engagement, has more impact.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="07a28664-a3cb-4a39-a869-002c455e1c47"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="07a28664-a3cb-4a39-a869-002c455e1c47" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Vignesh Wadarajan, “Loyalty programs: What works and what doesn’t,” <em>Forbes</em>, November 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In light of these consumer landscape changes, real estate companies should contemplate three paradigm shifts.</p>
<ul>
    <li>
    <p><em>From commodity to segment-specific community.</em> Scaled residential players can contemplate how to build meaningful experiences tailored to specific market segments. Communities can be based around shared values, interests, or priorities. For example, a brand could be known for focusing on providing goods and services (including furniture and recreation) that account for 38 percent of typical household spending.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6d607d93-c179-426b-a15d-8fa0db102748"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6d607d93-c179-426b-a15d-8fa0db102748" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">US Bureau of Labor Statistics Consumer Expenditure Survey. Includes rent, furnishings and durable household goods, recreational services, and food services.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
    <p>As companies think about building brands, it’s useful to consider sea changes reshaping tenant expectations. As more people work from home, residential complexes may be supplanting workplaces as places of interpersonal connection. A recent poll found that 55 percent of Americans in 2023 placed high importance on community activities, up from 29 percent in 2001.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f83728ba-36b7-4725-af78-5f6932b799cf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f83728ba-36b7-4725-af78-5f6932b799cf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Frank Newport, “Measuring trends in Americans’ personal values,” Gallup, November 20, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Brands could provide a sense of belonging that is increasingly important to consumers. Real estate companies tell us that when a resident reports that they know someone else in the community, they are more likely to renew their lease. It may be easier to leave four impersonal walls than it is to leave a social circle.</p>
    </li>
    <li><em>From one-size-fits-all to personalized experiences.</em> Once a resident chooses a home in which the brand dovetails with their lifestyle aspirations, they still want to be treated as an individual within that building. A resident who feels that the property owner handles the important moments (including when they move into the building, receive visitors, and need maintenance) in a way that caters to their individual needs is likely to feel more loyal to the brand behind that building. Not only could this make them want to stay, but when that tenant needs to move, they may be more likely to seek another home from within the brand family.</li>
    <li>
    <p><em>From delayed and manual to AI-enabled instant gratification.</em> Management activities including leasing, renewals, and completing service requests are often handled in an analog way. This can lead to wait times and experiences that don’t meet the on-demand mindsets of today’s consumers. Real estate companies can transform operations to blend the best of human and digital interaction, rising to the response expectations of residents. Leading real estate companies are already responding—we have seen companies automate more than 70 percent of interactions, using AI companions and other tools.</p>
    <p>The result can be meaningful value: we have observed real estate companies digitally rewire and subsequently enjoy 2 to 4 percent NOI increases, plus additional value from the sale of ancillary services (including event space rentals, cleaning services, and grocery delivery). We’ve seen even further NOI gains from operating efficiencies.</p>
    </li>
</ul>
<h2>Eight steps to building loyalty-inspiring residential experiences</h2>
<p>Resident loyalty—and NOI growth—sprouts from a foundation made up of digitally enabled customer experiences and strong brand equity. The challenge for C-suite leaders is to pursue these objectives simultaneously while building an individual brand or brand network. Here’s an eight-step guide to tackling these objectives.</p>
<h3>1. Determine the brand target (the ‘who’)</h3>
<p>Using a combination of attitudinal, psychographic, and behavioral factors, identify the segment of residents a particular brand and associated set of properties are intended to serve. Properties can be thought of as giant, digitally enabled smart products built to serve a particular segment of residents. For example, an MFR-provided home can be <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/a-better-way-to-build-a-brand-the-community-flywheel">oriented around a set of shared values</a> (including sustainability), hobbies (including fitness), or lifestyle factors (including walkability or proximity to a highway), all of which can help attract more members of that figurative “tribe.”</p>
<h3>2. Define what is meaningful to each community (the ‘why’)</h3>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Branded–owned residential blazes a trail</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Owned residential</strong> has seen a proliferation of properties linked to luxury hotel, car, and retail brands.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b5832689-88a9-472e-aff7-def09a3c4bac"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b5832689-88a9-472e-aff7-def09a3c4bac" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Debra Kamin, “The latest cool amenity? A name brand. How about Porsche?,” <em>New York Times</em>, September 15, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Many of these branded properties have sold at 5 to 50 percent premiums over comparable properties, according to McKinsey’s research, underscoring the power of brands to create clear expectations.</p>
<p>By helping residents envision living as they do in their favorite hotels, and then translating the quality promise of a high-fashion brand or luxury vehicle, branded residential has created communities bonded by common passions and values. More recently, residential properties have partnered with fitness and wellness brands. The success of these brands in owned residential serves as an intriguing model for single-family residential and multifamily residential properties.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Identify what the company is promoting that is distinctive now and is likely to remain so (see sidebar “Branded–owned residential blazes a trail”). As long as companies are tailored to a particular segment of interest, perceived benefits can be practical (such as being close to transportation) or emotional (such as joining a community of like-minded people). To illustrate the value that some tenants place on sustainability or technology features: renters report a willingness to pay 1.0 to 5.0 percent (average 1.8 percent) more for one level higher of energy efficiency<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="42ea87f3-c112-4811-a1cb-2213ce897679"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="42ea87f3-c112-4811-a1cb-2213ce897679" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Hannah Bastian et al., <em>Energy labels affect behavior on rental listing websites: A controlled experiment</em>, American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, May 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>; renters interested in smart devices report being willing to pay 2 to 3 percent more for a single smart device (Exhibit 1).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cdd9b7a9-419d-490b-a244-7d6bb4e30fa9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cdd9b7a9-419d-490b-a244-7d6bb4e30fa9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Novid Parsi, “Renters want smart tech—and will pay for it, too,” Professional Builder, January 31, 2022; 2 to 3 percent statement is the result of McKinsey analysis, with the average at approximately $37 and the average rent in the United States being $1,700 per month.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<h3>3. Identify the moments that matter</h3>
<p>For the segment a brand seeks to serve, measure resident satisfaction at each journey stage (such as moving in, midway through lease, and at lease renewal) and understand which steps of the journey are most important to eliciting desired behaviors (such as lease signing, decision to renew, or likelihood to recommend the community to a friend or family member). The goal is to land upon moments that delight, but also that elicit economic returns for the property (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/real%20estate/our%20insights/the%20new%20real%20estate%20investment%20edge%20tech%20enabled%20brand%20cx%20and%20loyalty/svgz-realestatecx-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Real estate operators can transform standard tenant interactions into branded moments of delight." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/real%20estate/our%20insights/the%20new%20real%20estate%20investment%20edge%20tech%20enabled%20brand%20cx%20and%20loyalty/svgz-realestatecx-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <h3>4. Customize the residential experience</h3>
<p>Real estate is both physical and digital, therefore it’s critical to think about the product as the combination of a standout property and the human and technology-based interactions within it.</p>
<p>Smart technology is one increasingly attractive way to activate physical spaces. For example, a smart thermostat linked to a sensor on heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) units can allow a resident to turn on the air-conditioning before they get home, balancing comfort with sustainability. An automated nudge can inform a resident that turning down their thermostat by a few degrees could help them spend closer to the building average on heating and cooling and enable them to adjust the temperature remotely. Sensors can detect unusual behavior (for example, if the apartment takes too long to cool down) and alert maintenance teams to issues before they become problems. A leak sensor can play the same role, detecting small drips of water under the sink or behind the dishwasher before they become floods (Exhibit 3).</p>
<p>Customization can also be about highlighting building amenities that matter to specific tenants. For example, a couple of weeks before a child’s birthday, a tenant could receive an offer to book the building’s party room. Or if the building is aware that a tenant is interested in fitness or nutrition, it can send out an invitation to a special yoga class or cooking demonstration that lets the tenant live their values.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Do airline customers</strong> crave service with a smile? A survey found they desired <em>less</em> face-to-face interaction. For example, 65 percent wanted touchless curb-to-cabin biometric checks, and 60 percent wanted digital passports, with data deleted after use.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="32b33ddd-3db3-4e09-a005-386dbeb710f6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="32b33ddd-3db3-4e09-a005-386dbeb710f6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Henry Canaday, “Digital tech is transforming the airport customer experience,” Aviation Week Network, September 29, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Answering the call for a more automated experience, one major airline drastically reduced service operations costs by introducing new digital touchpoints. Because they were less busy handling smaller, rote tasks, service staff could devote their time to resolving tricky issues. By creating a more seamless customer experience, the airline both lowered costs and increased customer satisfaction. Nearly three-quarters of customers reported preferring the new self-serve boarding process over the standard boarding procedure.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f59d538-a106-4e65-bf78-6f05d7362876"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f59d538-a106-4e65-bf78-6f05d7362876" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Diane Miller, “The digitization of customer experience and why it needs to be on your priority list,” SnapLogic, May 5, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>There’s an opportunity to apply established science from other industries to real estate. The travel industry’s research into personalization, digital marketing, and digitally enabled customer service—elements that optimize experience and generate loyalty—translates well. Seventy-nine percent of residents<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1859a163-9350-4d91-93cd-9f4eac188d10"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1859a163-9350-4d91-93cd-9f4eac188d10" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>An exploratory research study: Customer experience and customer self-support</em>, Higher Logic, April 19, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span>  prefer to tour properties, renew leases, submit maintenance requests, and interact with management through self-service means—freeing up staff time for more value-added tasks.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>To deliver memorable, branded touchpoints, operators will need an operating platform consisting of the right people, processes, data, and technology. This platform should enable the correct use of resident data and technology so that staff is empowered to make the best decisions. These will likely involve reimagining typical workforce operations and transforming day-to-day tasks with new tools (see sidebar “Incorporating automation can yield better service”). But a word of caution: parachuting new technology into a building that has a long-standing operating model in place won<span style="line-height:110%">’t</span> propel innovation. Instead, it’s important for a company or brand to be open to changing long-held processes, be willing to test and learn through pilots on a small subset of properties, and understand that not every experiment will succeed.</p>

With thousands of practitioners at QuantumBlack (data engineers, data scientists, product managers, designers, and software engineers) and McKinsey (industry and domain experts), we are working to solve the world’s most important AI challenges. QuantumBlack Labs is our center of technology development and client innovation, which has been driving cutting-edge advancements and developments in AI through locations across the globe.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Tools may include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Analytics-enabled services</em> can recognize and reward milestones (such as birthdays and anniversaries, or years of occupancy in the building) to optimize the customer experience.</li>
    <li><em>AI-powered copilots</em> can improve prospective residents’ experiences and free up frontline employees’ time by empowering them with better information (Exhibit 4). AI-powered workflow tools can provide coaching and insights that help building teams make better decisions about everything from capital expenditures for new building features to better revenue management.</li>
    <li><em>AI-enabled workload forecasting and dynamic scheduling models</em> can optimize labor levels based on seasonal demand, enabling intelligent labor forecasting and budgeting.</li>
    <li><em>Intelligent, self-serve resident support portals</em> can answer frequently asked questions and enable digital workflows (including rent payments and maintenance request submissions).</li>
    <li><em>Digitally enabled community activation</em>, delivered through a mobile app, enables residents to learn about and RSVP to events that help them feel connected to their neighbors.</li>
</ul>

<h3>6. Define the governing brand architecture</h3>
<p>Real estate companies can <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-brand-behind-the-brands">create their own brands</a> or partner with established brands that already enjoy strong public recognition. Brand strategy decisions should be made after researching conversion, loyalty, pricing premiums, and retention. If there is a loyalty program, decide whether it relates to the specific building or to the parent brand. Creating brand families starts with deciding which of the following models is most beneficial:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Brand house.</em> All subbrands are logically associated with the parent brand, enabling strong network lifestyle recognition that is consistent across geographies. This approach is most effective when:
    <ul>
        <li>resident segment needs are almost identical</li>
        <li>the brand contains and communicates all relevant dimensions and benefits</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><em>Endorsed model.</em> Subbrands resemble the parent brand, exhibiting some overlap in user segments, user needs, or product offerings. This is most effective when:
    <ul>
        <li>resident segments share few comparable needs</li>
        <li>subbrand identities are loosely based on the parent brand</li>
        <li>the parent brand imparts trust and credibility to the subbrands</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
    <li><em>House of brands.</em> This refers to a brand umbrella, in which sub-building brands have stronger recognition than the network parent brand. Each brand has a different user segment and brand ethos. This is most effective when:
    <ul>
        <li>each brand addresses a segment with unique needs</li>
        <li>brands are perceived as most relevant to consumer segments when positioned individually</li>
    </ul>
    </li>
</ul>
<h3>7. Be bold</h3>
<p><a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-future-of-brand-strategy-its-time-to-go-electric">Highly creative brands consistently outperform their peers</a>, with 67 percent achieving above-average organic revenue growth. Building an engaging, high-performing brand is an agile exercise, and brands have to evolve to maintain relevance and meaning for the communities they serve.</p>
<h3>8. Measure and focus on data</h3>
<p>Bold experimentation is crucial but can only yield results when it’s measured. Companies have to be able to quantify the impact of their experiments to know what worked, what didn’t, and how to adjust. This requires investing in data, the bedrock of loyalty. Companies need data to understand their residents’ habits, values, and behaviors. Data collection and synthesis tools include customer relationship management technologies, sensors that measure amenity use, social media listening tools, and surveys.</p>
<hr>
<p>In the new world of customer experience, resident expectations are evolving. Residents live in a world where hotels, cars, fitness communities, and more are imbued with polished self-service, nuanced brand identities, and sophisticated loyalty programs. It’s logical that they should want these same attributes in the places they call home. Now it’s up to real estate owners and operators to recognize the call for change and to deliver it through branded moments that matter.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Alex Wolkomir</strong> is a partner in McKinsey’s New York office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/vaibhav-gujral">Vaibhav Gujral</a></strong> is a senior partner and <strong>Laura Campbell</strong> and <strong>Nicolette Lewis</strong> are associate partners; <strong>Michael Hales</strong> is a partner in the Chicago office; and <strong>Sam O’Gorman</strong> is an associate partner in the London office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Corinne Beemer, Amanda Felberg, Ethan Henley, Bo Johns-Hennessy, Kelsey Muller, Dmitry Shatalin, and Yue Wu for their contributions to this article.</p>

<i>McKinsey Quarterly</i></span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"The new real estate investment edge Tech enabled brand CX and loyalty","displayName":"The new real estate investment edge Tech enabled brand CX and loyalty","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"f4103040-87da-486a-ae89-8f3be6814fcf","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The new real estate investment edge: Tech-enabled brand, CX, and loyalty"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"The CX edge in real estate"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Superior customer experience in real estate combines evocative brands, memorable moments, and low-cost operations."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"We look at why superior customer experience (CX) in real estate combines evocative brands, memorable moments, and low-cost operations."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-05-15T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCustomer experience (CX) and loyalty\u003c/strong\u003e are ubiquitous concepts in consumer-facing industries. But in the real estate world, only the hospitality sector is known for a laser focus on consumer experiences that inspire customer loyalty and build brands. It doesn\u0026rsquo;t have to be this way. Large single-family residential (SFR) and multifamily residential (MFR) platforms now have the scale to build brands that clearly communicate a quality promise and make tenants want to stay.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eWith an array of premium finishes and residential amenities now commonplace, real estate operators are increasingly aware that economic returns often hinge on creating memorable moments for tenants. What might not be as obvious is the sea change in CX, which has long been understood to involve putting more money and personnel behind a property. The radical difference in 2024 is that operators can upgrade the tenant experience while also saving money\u0026mdash;and in a way that can yield better returns for properties. At a time when the high cost of real estate is a major tenant concern, a way to improve the offering without increasing costs can be a welcome innovation for numerous stakeholders.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eMemorable brand experiences, combined with the right data and technology to personalize touchpoints\u0026mdash;including generative AI (gen AI) and digital marketing platforms\u0026mdash;can stimulate willingness to choose a given property, higher renewal rates, and lifetime loyalty. Our experience working with numerous residential players has demonstrated that there is a premium of up to 15 percent between the highest- and lowest-performing players in a market, controlled for similar building characteristics (such as location, age, and amenities).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe highest-performing companies have numerous things in common, including technology investments that enable personalization (such as emails that remember a tenant\u0026rsquo;s birthday or pet\u0026rsquo;s name), new operating and staffing models (such as centralized leasing and renewals teams that serve multiple buildings), investments in brand advertising, and digital touchpoints that create transparency (such as an app for tenants to check on the status of maintenance requests). Tenants clearly perceive more value in buildings managed this way, and this value flows directly to top-line revenue and net operating income (NOI).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo be sure, technology is never the stand-alone superstar. Instead, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/rewired-to-outcompete\"\u003ewhen companies rewire to create new ways of working\u003c/a\u003e, tech can enable fresh ways to operate and serve residents. The key for residential real estate owners and operators is to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/how-generative-ai-can-boost-consumer-marketing\"\u003edefine the CX moments that matter\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;along a resident\u0026rsquo;s journey, underpinned by a branded North Star.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article describes how real estate companies can approach CX to encourage loyalty and build brands imbued with meaning by using an eight-step framework. For the purposes of this article, loyalty refers to tenants who perceive value in a real estate brand and respond by either renewing leases or looking for their next home within the same family of brands.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow residential real estate can react to a shifting experiential landscape\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross industries, changing consumer interaction preferences and a proliferation of new technologies, including AI, are enabling companies to interact with customers in new and creative ways. In the post-COVID-19 landscape, proactive self-service that concretely answers specific questions is often customers\u0026rsquo; first choice, preferred over interacting with a sales representative.[[footnote 1]] \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/next-in-loyalty-eight-levers-to-turn-customers-into-fans\"\u003eLoyalty is an evolving concept\u003c/a\u003e, partly because consumers often drop out of loyalty programs after reaping the sign-up reward.[[footnote 2]] Instead, an omnichannel strategy, whereby consumers interact with brands across platforms and continually receive personalized recognition for their engagement, has more impact.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn light of these consumer landscape changes, real estate companies should contemplate three paradigm shifts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrom commodity to segment-specific community.\u003c/em\u003e Scaled residential players can contemplate how to build meaningful experiences tailored to specific market segments. Communities can be based around shared values, interests, or priorities. For example, a brand could be known for focusing on providing goods and services (including furniture and recreation) that account for 38 percent of typical household spending.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eAs companies think about building brands, it\u0026rsquo;s useful to consider sea changes reshaping tenant expectations. As more people work from home, residential complexes may be supplanting workplaces as places of interpersonal connection. A recent poll found that 55 percent of Americans in 2023 placed high importance on community activities, up from 29 percent in 2001.[[footnote 5]] Brands could provide a sense of belonging that is increasingly important to consumers. Real estate companies tell us that when a resident reports that they know someone else in the community, they are more likely to renew their lease. It may be easier to leave four impersonal walls than it is to leave a social circle.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrom one-size-fits-all to personalized experiences.\u003c/em\u003e Once a resident chooses a home in which the brand dovetails with their lifestyle aspirations, they still want to be treated as an individual within that building. A resident who feels that the property owner handles the important moments (including when they move into the building, receive visitors, and need maintenance) in a way that caters to their individual needs is likely to feel more loyal to the brand behind that building. Not only could this make them want to stay, but when that tenant needs to move, they may be more likely to seek another home from within the brand family.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrom delayed and manual to AI-enabled instant gratification.\u003c/em\u003e Management activities including leasing, renewals, and completing service requests are often handled in an analog way. This can lead to wait times and experiences that don\u0026rsquo;t meet the on-demand mindsets of today\u0026rsquo;s consumers. Real estate companies can transform operations to blend the best of human and digital interaction, rising to the response expectations of residents. Leading real estate companies are already responding\u0026mdash;we have seen companies automate more than 70 percent of interactions, using AI companions and other tools.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003eThe result can be meaningful value: we have observed real estate companies digitally rewire and subsequently enjoy 2 to 4 percent NOI increases, plus additional value from the sale of ancillary services (including event space rentals, cleaning services, and grocery delivery). We\u0026rsquo;ve seen even further NOI gains from operating efficiencies.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEight steps to building loyalty-inspiring residential experiences\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResident loyalty\u0026mdash;and NOI growth\u0026mdash;sprouts from a foundation made up of digitally enabled customer experiences and strong brand equity. The challenge for C-suite leaders is to pursue these objectives simultaneously while building an individual brand or brand network. Here\u0026rsquo;s an eight-step guide to tackling these objectives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Determine the brand target (the \u0026lsquo;who\u0026rsquo;)\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUsing a combination of attitudinal, psychographic, and behavioral factors, identify the segment of residents a particular brand and associated set of properties are intended to serve. Properties can be thought of as giant, digitally enabled smart products built to serve a particular segment of residents. For example, an MFR-provided home can be \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/a-better-way-to-build-a-brand-the-community-flywheel\"\u003eoriented around a set of shared values\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(including sustainability), hobbies (including fitness), or lifestyle factors (including walkability or proximity to a highway), all of which can help attract more members of that figurative \u0026ldquo;tribe.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Define what is meaningful to each community (the \u0026lsquo;why\u0026rsquo;)\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eIdentify what the company is promoting that is distinctive now and is likely to remain so (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Branded\u0026ndash;owned residential blazes a trail\u0026rdquo;). As long as companies are tailored to a particular segment of interest, perceived benefits can be practical (such as being close to transportation) or emotional (such as joining a community of like-minded people). To illustrate the value that some tenants place on sustainability or technology features: renters report a willingness to pay 1.0 to 5.0 percent (average 1.8 percent) more for one level higher of energy efficiency[[footnote 6]]; renters interested in smart devices report being willing to pay 2 to 3 percent more for a single smart device (Exhibit 1).[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Identify the moments that matter\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor the segment a brand seeks to serve, measure resident satisfaction at each journey stage (such as moving in, midway through lease, and at lease renewal) and understand which steps of the journey are most important to eliciting desired behaviors (such as lease signing, decision to renew, or likelihood to recommend the community to a friend or family member). The goal is to land upon moments that delight, but also that elicit economic returns for the property (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Customize the residential experience\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReal estate is both physical and digital, therefore it\u0026rsquo;s critical to think about the product as the combination of a standout property and the human and technology-based interactions within it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSmart technology is one increasingly attractive way to activate physical spaces. For example, a smart thermostat linked to a sensor on heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) units can allow a resident to turn on the air-conditioning before they get home, balancing comfort with sustainability. An automated nudge can inform a resident that turning down their thermostat by a few degrees could help them spend closer to the building average on heating and cooling and enable them to adjust the temperature remotely. Sensors can detect unusual behavior (for example, if the apartment takes too long to cool down) and alert maintenance teams to issues before they become problems. A leak sensor can play the same role, detecting small drips of water under the sink or behind the dishwasher before they become floods (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCustomization can also be about highlighting building amenities that matter to specific tenants. For example, a couple of weeks before a child\u0026rsquo;s birthday, a tenant could receive an offer to book the building\u0026rsquo;s party room. Or if the building is aware that a tenant is interested in fitness or nutrition, it can send out an invitation to a special yoga class or cooking demonstration that lets the tenant live their values.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch3\u003e5. Enable CX differentiators with technology, people, and processes\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo deliver memorable, branded touchpoints, operators will need an operating platform consisting of the right people, processes, data, and technology. This platform should enable the correct use of resident data and technology so that staff is empowered to make the best decisions. These will likely involve reimagining typical workforce operations and transforming day-to-day tasks with new tools (see sidebar \u0026ldquo;Incorporating automation can yield better service\u0026rdquo;). But a word of caution: parachuting new technology into a building that has a long-standing operating model in place won\u003cspan style=\"line-height: 110%;\"\u003e\u0026rsquo;t\u003c/span\u003e propel innovation. Instead, it\u0026rsquo;s important for a company or brand to be open to changing long-held processes, be willing to test and learn through pilots on a small subset of properties, and understand that not every experiment will succeed.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[globalsidebar QB]]\n\u003cp\u003eTools may include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnalytics-enabled services\u003c/em\u003e can recognize and reward milestones (such as birthdays and anniversaries, or years of occupancy in the building) to optimize the customer experience.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAI-powered copilots\u003c/em\u003e can improve prospective residents\u0026rsquo; experiences and free up frontline employees\u0026rsquo; time by empowering them with better information (Exhibit 4). AI-powered workflow tools can provide coaching and insights that help building teams make better decisions about everything from capital expenditures for new building features to better revenue management.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAI-enabled workload forecasting and dynamic scheduling models\u003c/em\u003e can optimize labor levels based on seasonal demand, enabling intelligent labor forecasting and budgeting.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntelligent, self-serve resident support portals\u003c/em\u003e can answer frequently asked questions and enable digital workflows (including rent payments and maintenance request submissions).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDigitally enabled community activation\u003c/em\u003e, delivered through a mobile app, enables residents to learn about and RSVP to events that help them feel connected to their neighbors.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch3\u003e6. Define the governing brand architecture\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReal estate companies can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-brand-behind-the-brands\"\u003ecreate their own brands\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;or partner with established brands that already enjoy strong public recognition. Brand strategy decisions should be made after researching conversion, loyalty, pricing premiums, and retention. If there is a loyalty program, decide whether it relates to the specific building or to the parent brand. Creating brand families starts with deciding which of the following models is most beneficial:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBrand house.\u003c/em\u003e All subbrands are logically associated with the parent brand, enabling strong network lifestyle recognition that is consistent across geographies. This approach is most effective when:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eresident segment needs are almost identical\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003ethe brand contains and communicates all relevant dimensions and benefits\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEndorsed model.\u003c/em\u003e Subbrands resemble the parent brand, exhibiting some overlap in user segments, user needs, or product offerings. This is most effective when:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eresident segments share few comparable needs\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003esubbrand identities are loosely based on the parent brand\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003ethe parent brand imparts trust and credibility to the subbrands\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHouse of brands.\u003c/em\u003e This refers to a brand umbrella, in which sub-building brands have stronger recognition than the network parent brand. Each brand has a different user segment and brand ethos. This is most effective when:\n    \u003cul\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eeach brand addresses a segment with unique needs\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003ebrands are perceived as most relevant to consumer segments when positioned individually\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ul\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e7. Be bold\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-future-of-brand-strategy-its-time-to-go-electric\"\u003eHighly creative brands consistently outperform their peers\u003c/a\u003e, with 67 percent achieving above-average organic revenue growth. Building an engaging, high-performing brand is an agile exercise, and brands have to evolve to maintain relevance and meaning for the communities they serve.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e8. Measure and focus on data\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBold experimentation is crucial but can only yield results when it\u0026rsquo;s measured. Companies have to be able to quantify the impact of their experiments to know what worked, what didn\u0026rsquo;t, and how to adjust. This requires investing in data, the bedrock of loyalty. Companies need data to understand their residents\u0026rsquo; habits, values, and behaviors. Data collection and synthesis tools include customer relationship management technologies, sensors that measure amenity use, social media listening tools, and surveys.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the new world of customer experience, resident expectations are evolving. Residents live in a world where hotels, cars, fitness communities, and more are imbued with polished self-service, nuanced brand identities, and sophisticated loyalty programs. It\u0026rsquo;s logical that they should want these same attributes in the places they call home. Now it\u0026rsquo;s up to real estate owners and operators to recognize the call for change and to deliver it through branded moments that matter.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":false},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-05-15T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eStephanie Clifford, \u0026ldquo;Retailers add gadgets for shoppers at ease with technology,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eNew York Times\u003c/em\u003e, March 9, 2012.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eNathaniel Meyersohn, \u0026ldquo;Best Buy, Dunkin\u0026rsquo; and Starbucks changed their rewards programs. seen a proliferation of properties linked to luxury hotel, car, and retail brands.[[footnote 1]] Many of these branded properties have sold at 5 to 50 percent premiums over comparable properties, according to McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s research, underscoring the power of brands to create clear expectations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy helping residents envision living as they do in their favorite hotels, and then translating the quality promise of a high-fashion brand or luxury vehicle, branded residential has created communities bonded by common passions and values. More recently, residential properties have partnered with fitness and wellness brands. The success of these brands in owned residential serves as an intriguing model for single-family residential and multifamily residential properties.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Branded–owned residential blazes a trail"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDebra Kamin, \u0026ldquo;The latest cool amenity? A survey found they desired \u003cem\u003eless\u003c/em\u003e face-to-face interaction. For example, 65 percent wanted touchless curb-to-cabin biometric checks, and 60 percent wanted digital passports, with data deleted after use.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnswering the call for a more automated experience, one major airline drastically reduced service operations costs by introducing new digital touchpoints. Because they were less busy handling smaller, rote tasks, service staff could devote their time to resolving tricky issues. By creating a more seamless customer experience, the airline both lowered costs and increased customer satisfaction. Nearly three-quarters of customers reported preferring the new self-serve boarding process over the standard boarding procedure.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s an opportunity to apply established science from other industries to real estate. The travel industry\u0026rsquo;s research into personalization, digital marketing, and digitally enabled customer service\u0026mdash;elements that optimize experience and generate loyalty\u0026mdash;translates well.
